content:
Hey all -- meeting in ~3 minutes.

Today's agenda:

  • Release retrospective
@T-release meeting!
only half, listening, not feeling great today
Ok - let's get started
I'm not actually sure that too much went wrong this release, which seems positive
@Pietro Albini ran the release pretty smoothly from what I noticed at least :)
yeah only had a bit of trouble with haunted CI for beta
but in general it's been way less painful than the previous ones
the -stable builder and the effort to backport beta patches to master seems to have worked :)

I think one thing that might be useful to discuss a little is release note drafting -- we're pretty regularly in a bit of a rush to get those landed and fixed up at the end of the cycle. I'm wondering if there's more we can do to automate/maintain a list of pending tasks/help out @XAMPPRocky there
@XAMPPRocky do you have thoughts on this?
It was slightly concerning how no one was quite sure what exactly was being stabilised with the macros in built-in attributes
Well the release notes for 1.55 are already up.
Yeah, release notes are usually up in plenty of time, it's more the long tail of fixes/comments that I'm not quite sure we're managing so well
(In particular I'm usually feeling pretty uncertain about the compat notes, for example)
Well earlier reviews are definitely appreciated, it does feel like that stuff comes pretty late sometimes.

Hm. I know I saw a comment on reddit on some of the reviews not being addressed -- I wonder if we should maintain a dedicated list of pending things to include that's less "github comments" and more checkboxes or something?
I know I'm never too sure if I need to be re-pinging you or what the state is on things
didn't we enable some fancy beta GitHub stuff for that?

Like I also wonder how much we should we keep it open throughout the release, and if it would be better to merge the big PR sooner, and follow it up with smaller PRs. That might make it harder to backport (? Not sure)
Backporting we do by just grabbing the file (not individual commits), or at least, that's what I do
I think many small PRs might be a good idea.
@simulacrum Do you have an example, I don’t remember any comments being unaddressed.
I think the reddit user was noting that we missed 1.54 adding noalias
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/86696#issuecomment-875530097
incremental compilation was also missed, but I'm not sure anyone commented on that in the pr
I think both of these may not have had proper milestone labels, from the weird way they "landed"
i.e. the "new" thing was inaction, that we didn't turn them off in this release
yeah, maybe
(I guess that speaks to only disabling on beta being a bad thing...?)
or we need some other way to track such things
Yeah, I remember not adding immediately because we had pulled it out before, and must have forgotten to put it in before the end.
hm
well, seems like we can try merging immediately for the 1.55 cycle at least
(or well, much faster)
and see what effect that has
SGTM
ok
@triagebot end-topic on release notes

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
alright
and @triagebot end-topic on retrospective (I'm not sure there's anything else for this cycle)

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
@triagebot end-meeting then?

Does anyone have something to bring up?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if you're ready to end the meeting.
alright
thanks everyone!
Oh sorry
I have something
oh, go ahead then :)
We’ll have to take it private, as it’s bit sensitive so one moment while I group DM you all.
:thumbs_up:
Hey @simulacrum , I saw up above you touched on release notes topics
I wanted to ask: What are your thoughts about how/whether to keep RELEASES.md and the blog post in sync?
(or ensuring that RELEASES.md contains a super-set of info that is on blog post, I guess…)
@pnkfelix What would happen in your mind when they’re not in sync?
well, the only real issue is that some users get surprised. E.g. carol10cents just posted on the incr-comp bug
because carol had only looked at RELEASES.md, not the blog post
and I can understand the thinking, that RELEASES.md is a useful central point of info about the changes over time
Will get back to you after our private discussion ends
@pnkfelix Sure, I’m more trying to imagine what the solution would look like. Like it’s not as simple as link checking since the blog post could link to more material than the release notes.

@pnkfelix Yeah, I think in general we want this to be true. We can edit blog post until the last minute, but release notes have (at least) a few hours of latency before we can edit them as they need to go through bors.
I would definitely not object to a PR updating 1.54 to include incr and noalias being enabled

XAMPPRocky said:

We’ll have to take it private, as it’s bit sensitive so one moment while I group DM you all.

what would it take for us to get a t-release/private stream?
I can set it up (we just haven't needed it yet).

XAMPPRocky said:

pnkfelix Sure, I’m more trying to imagine what the solution would look like. Like it’s not as simple as link checking since the blog post could link to more material than the release notes.

Right. The options I can imagine are: (1.) playbook for writing release updates, that specifically points out one should (at minimum) update RELEASES.md, and after that consider whether section in blog post is also warranted. (Such a playbook might already exist for all I know), (2.) link checking is an interesting idea, but you’re right that its probably not quite right. But some kind of consistency check between the two could be interesting; e.g. maybe for every section of release blog post, there should exist at least one sentence in the section that corresponds to a RELEASES.md entry? (Do some kind of fuzzy matching of the words to allow for slight deviations.) That may be a bit extreme, I admit.
I would generally consider the blog post to be temporally pinpointed, receiving only minor fixes, while RELEASES.md is the living document
I think there's no need for a technical measure to control this -- but yeah, I agree with @cuviper that the blog is a snapshot and release notes are the living version.
Okay, so we can just update RELEASES.md as necessary to reflect the points that we realize matter, even after the release comes out. That seems fine to me.

XAMPPRocky said:

It was slightly concerning how no one was quite sure what exactly was being stabilised with the macros in built-in attributes

is there a way I could have explained it better? It did seem like people understood the main idea, they were just not sure about some of the technical details, which I wouldn't expect to be called out in the release notes
also there weren't questions about it until very late, so I didn't have much time to respond

@Joshua Nelson I don't know if there's a solution, it's just one little nit right now, I brought up so that if it happens again with other features in the project, we might have a problem at that point.
